title: League client update alpha sign-ups now open

replies.body:
"We’re searching for level 30 players who often queue up with friends."

It never stops does it, lol.

im still waiting :(

two questions:

1. Does testing on Linux have any sway in one direction or another for this? I want to see how well it will work under Wine. 

2. How do you know my "computer specs?" Rather, when are these gathered? Today I signed up via a laptop, but the computer I usually use is a desktop with a 980ti and an i5 4570k - so I'm hoping you determine computer specs while we are playing league and not when we sign up.

Heyo! Great questions :)

1) Anyone can sign-up, so feel free to express interest! Once we send out invites to those accepted, there will be a download link included, so if you're approved you could test that out under Wine, if you prefer.

2) We don't collect your specs at sign-up, only when you're using the client (playing the game).

While we're on the topic of Linux, are there any plans on making an actual native Linux client? While the game technically _works_ in wine it has by far the worst performance of all the major esports games right now. Starcraft 2 and Hearthstone both perform excellent in wine, DotA2 and CS:GO even works natively, but playing League on Linux my computer barely manages 30fps in teamfights on medium settings while I never dropped below 144fps on the highest settings under Windows.

I'm fully aware Linux users are a small nieche out of League's huge playerbase and that we're likely not a priority, but it really sadens me how poor my favorite game performs in my favorit OS.

There are no plans at this time to make a native Linux client. Hopefully the updated client will run better for you under Wine, but we're not testing for that as it's not officially supported. Feel free to still sign up for the test, and you can give it a go if you get in.

What's regarded as a history of "negative in-game behavior"? I've most probably been reported by salty teammates in the past following arguments in-game, but I've never been punished by Riot. Are you guys only accepting report-free players, or do you only have a blot on your record if you've been actively punished?
We're referring to those who have been punished, not those who have just been reported.

What's the reasoning behind this? Is it similar to sandbox where you believe it'll lead to toxicity? 

"Wow your so bad, I get to test new client and you dont, your trash uninstall" or something of the matter.

It has more to do with the attitude of the person and the desire of Riot to have a positive testing environment. I doubt a habitually toxic player would be that good at providing feedback on the testing and a positive environment makes it easier for other people to test things out and report the feedback from that. 

Think of it like an IRL experiment. The scientist would prefer to pick the person that is nice and cooperative than the others that curse a lot and like condescending against others and being generally mean to other people.

Why would a toxic player be bad at providing feedback, makes no sense at all.

Maybe they want only non toxic players so they only get positive feedback and no criticism.

Not being toxic does not equal being unable to provide criticism. I think the reasoning simply is that if you behave well in game you also get some perks, like being able to try out the new client during alpha. It's simply another way of discouraging toxicity.

It seems they are just trying to have this taken as seriously as possible since it has such a large impact. I don't think anyone will be able to tell another person is using the alpha client from their perspective so that argument wouldn't really be valid.
